awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of an FEI Apreo Scanning Electron Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of North Carolina Wilmington to acquire an FEI-Apreo Scanning electron Microscope (SEM).  The SEM will be a cornerstone of the undergraduate curriculum in introductory and advanced cell biology teaching. The educational benefits will be further extended to pre-college students through collaboration with the UNCW STEM Learning Cooperative, with a special focus on girls from underrepresented communities. The SEM will be used to conduct an integrative multi-year project that involves graduate and undergraduate students developing 3D visualization methods for microscopic specimens and production of 3D printed replicas of these specimens. Students will collaborate with pre-college teens to image, explore and produce models that can be used as educational material in their own schools. The SEM will provide regular outreach opportunities for science fairs, college open days, and life-long learning events that engage the general public in microscopy-based STEM. The award will therefore enable continued implementation of The University of North Carolina Wilmington's high-impact education and public outreach activities that are crosscutting, from K-12 through Ph.D.

The award will allow for high resolution imaging and microanalysis of surface structures of cells and tissues, biominerals, geological and paleontological samples, manufactured materials, and nanoparticles. Specifically, five thematic clusters of research will be supported: (1) Cell biology, taxonomy, and diversity of marine algae, (2) marine invertebrate and microbial symbiont diversity,  (3) angiosperm functional diversity and biogeography, (4) morphology and microstructure of cetaceans and their parasites, and (5) archeology, marine palentology, and sedimentary petrology. In addition to these research themes, many other projects, new research initiatives, and national and international collaborations will be facilitated by this award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington

por.por_cntn:
The ApreoS scanning electron microscope funded by this award was acquired and installed in the Summer 2020 after a lengthy delay due to building damage sustained by UNCW campus during Hurricane Florence in Fall 2018. As part of the necessary rebuilding and renovation we were able to reconfigure the Richard M. Dillaman Bioimaging facility space to optimize use of the microscope prior to installation. This included new flooring and walls, wiring, casework, low dust tiles, acoustic drywall, acoustic tiles, and relevant pipe work. The ApreoS scanning electron microscope now resides in a space that allows greater occupancy for teaching, training, demonstrations, and outreach activities. The SEM room was also upgraded with acoustic paneling and a large wall-mounted TV/monitor to project the microscope interface to promote covid-19-safe teaching and training.  Official occupancy of Dobo Hall (that houses the Bioimaging Facility) was permitted 8/10/2020 and the ApreoS scanning electron microscope has since supported a wide range of undergraduate and graduate teaching including a dedicated SEM training course in Spring 2021, an electron microscopy course in Fall 2021, and an Advanced Cell and Molecular Biology with Bioimaging course in Spring 2022. In spite of Covid-19 pandemic restrictions throughout the first year of operation, a total of 44 students benefited from this training, 2 graduate theses were completed, and several graduate projects using scanning electron microscopy were initiated.  The principle investigator and dedicated microscopy specialist attended a total of 11 days of professional training (5 days on-line, 7 days in person) provided by the manufacturers of the microscope and associated x-ray microanalysis system. This insured optimal management and performance of the system. A wide range of grant funded research was also supported in the first year of commission including; Characterization of biomineralization in marine phytoplankton that are important in ocean carbon cycling;  Understanding the development of fish olfactory organ in farm-raised and wild salmon; Examining the effects of microfiber ingestion on growth and performance of the commercially important black sea bass, and; Characterizing microbial associations with, and novel antimicrobial peptides from Antarctic copepod embryos. Moreover, the availability of the scanning electron microscope has supported multiple federal and international grant submissions and the planning of outreach activities targeted to K-12 and precollege students from communities underrepresented in STEM fields. The ApreoS scanning electron microscope is now firmly at the core of ongoing bioimaging research, training, and educational capability and represents a start-of-the-art instrument that is unparalleled in the region of SE North Carolina.

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2022
Modified by: Alison R Taylor
